awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Synergistic Computational, Experimental, and Thermoelectric Device-related Research for Multinary Chalcogenides with Earth-Abundant Constituents
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Reducing dependence on fossil fuels is a major challenge. In addition, there is direct correlation between energy use and economic development. Whether the focus is on reducing the depletion of natural resources, expanding the diversity of energy production, reduction in climate change, or achieving greater energy security, there is a growing need to use energy in a smarter manner, as well as generating energy from renewable sources. To this end, thermoelectricity, a solid-state scheme directly converting heat into electricity, can play a key role. Thermoelectric devices are especially attractive since they have no moving parts, are very reliable, ecologically clean, and allow for a wide range of industrial to consumer applications. A crucial aspect for commercial applications are materials with desired transport properties to maximize the efficiency of energy production. This project uses a synergistic approach, with computational, experimental, and device development aspects, to investigate a new class of materials with applications in thermoelectricity. These low-cost material systems have earth-abundant constituents that can be synthesized in high yields, which is especially attractive from both environmental and commercial perspectives. A fundamental understanding of these new materials is also important, and allows for rapid and effective development strategies for enhanced thermoelectric performance benefiting industrial development of clean, low cost thermoelectric power conversion devices.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: In this project, a new class of multinary chalcogenides composed of earth-abundant constituents as thermoelectric materials is being explored. Thermodynamic phase stability calculations, electronic and phonon structure properties, and the governing transport mechanisms are being investigated using first principles simulations. Models for structure-property relations are being used for alloying and defect engineering in the laboratory in order to obtain compositions with optimized thermoelectric properties. Experimental synthesis and characterization serve as validation in addition to input towards further iterations with an eye to improving computational and theoretical models. Additional experimental capabilities and device development are provided by the partnership with Marlow Industries, Inc., a world leader in thermoelectric devices and applications. This collaborative project provides an excellent platform for graduate student engagement in the research, and outreach activities for high school students in the local urban and surrounding rural areas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The search for environmentally friendly avenues for clean, renewable energy production is directly related to finding novel materials and composites with suitable structural characteristics and transport properties. Thermoelectric devices have a unique place in environmentally friendly energy applications, since they operate based on entirely solid state schemes with no harmful gasses. Most of the current state of the art thermoelectric materials and composites typically involve toxic, expensive, and scarce elements, which greatly limit the safety and commercial benefits of the technology. The search for novel materials that use eco-friendly and earth-abundant components is at the forefront of our research. In this collaborative project, we utilize experimental, computational, and device prototype building to find new materials and strategies for low cost and environmentally-friendly materials with targeted transport properties.

Our fundamental discoveries during this project include new materials syntheses, novel conduction and phonon scattering processes, ab initio simulations of electronic structure, and device developments involving multinary chalcogenide materials. In particular, we find a rather straight forward approach: by starting from simpler binary materials we construct more complicated ternary and quaternary systems. Some of the properties of these new classes may be similar to their "parents", and yet they possess distinct characteristics depending on their chemical compositions/lattice structure. This cation mutation method was applied to predict a new class of quaternary chalcogenides which can take several types of lattice structures with many types of metallic atoms. It is this atomic and symmetry diversity that enables large electronic property tunability.

These predictions have been realized in our laboratory as several materials being synthesized via chemical low-cost techniques. Through extensive simulations signature characteristics in the electronic transport are identified and studied as the chemical compositions change. The transport mechanisms are studied experimentally showing a great diversity in terms of how large the passing currents, mobilities, and other properties can be. These are explained in terms of the electronic structure properties revealed by the simulations. While the electronic transport can vary significantly, we find that all materials from this class have a rather low thermal conductivity, which is especially suitable for thermoelectricity. We further find that regardless of the chemical composition or lattice structure these multinary chalcogenides have a low optical frequency phonon band hybridized with acoustic branches. This common anharmonic scattering mechanism, also related to the soft cation-chalcogen bonds, appears as an effective scattering mechanism for phonons. Nevertheless, one can further reduce or enhance the thermal conductivity by choosing a lattice with inherent disorder and/or atoms with larger mass deviations.

The experimental techniques and simulations strategies are also suitable for the prediction and realization of other materials. For example, we also report the synthesis of clathrates and Bi-based systems, which may also be suitable thermoelectrics. Additionally, we followed the cation mutation method and showed yet a new class of quaternary chalcogenides that takes a chalcopyrite lattice structure and can accommodate a large number of defects. In addition to the cation diversity, diversity in defects appear as new tunability factors for electronic and thermal transport. We have also found a unique method to manipulate thermoelectric transport using thermodynamical concepts. Through a coordinate transformation technique we propose new devices capable of cloaking, concentrating, rotating in desired directions of thermal and heat currents within a given region. The procedure, protected under an issued US patent, outlines the design of metamaterials capable of achieving this type of unique control for harnessing thermoelectric flow that maybe desired in many applications.

This project is well aligned with the goals of the National Science Foundation as it addresses challenges of sustainable supply, engineering, production, and use of chemicals and materials. We have advanced our fundamental understanding of a new class of quaternary chalcogenide materials. Utilizing state of the art computational and theoretical methods we have investigated and designed the electronic structure and phonon properties with the purpose of enhancing the thermoelectric performance of these materials. The outcomes from this work benefit not only materials science and condensed matter physics, but it also draws our attention to the economic and environmental impacts of thermoelectricity. The studied low-cost, environmentally safe materials for large yield synthesis are major contributions of this work towards the challenges of sustainable energy the nation is currently facing. This research has been an excellent opportunity for training graduate students. They have gained valuable experience in a multidisciplinary, team-oriented environment encompassing materials science, chemistry, physics and device development. Students involved in this project have participated in different internship programs, which have been instrumental for their job placement after obtaining their PhD degrees. We have also conducted significant outreach efforts by organizing summer physics programs for high school students from the Tampa Bay area. The program was quite popular and many participating students entered various universities and colleges (including University of South Florida) declaring STEM majors.
